choices.A: Polymorphic malware and secure code analysis

discussion.content: This question was in the exam :)
I think this is apt?
exfiltration appears to occur over months via uniform TTPs.This is APT

Similar Q in 002
Again, 9/10 times when a security exam lists APTs as an answer choice its usually the correct one.
its over long periods of time in different organizations using using the same ttp (tacticts techniques procedures) definately APT

questions.question_text:
A threat intelligence analyst who works for a technology firm received this report from a vendor.
"There has been an intellectual property theft campaign executed against organizations in the technology industry. Indicators for this activity are unique to each intrusion. The information that appears to be targeted is R&D data. The data exfiltration appears to occur over months via uniform TTPs. Please execute a defensive operation regarding this attack vector."
Which of the following combinations suggests how the threat should MOST likely be classified and the type of analysis that would be MOST helpful in protecting against this activity?

choices.D: Add the URL included in the .js file to the company's web proxy filter.
choices.B: Move the files from the NAS to a cloud-based storage solution.
choices.C: Set permissions on file shares to read-only.
choices.A: Disable access to the company VPN.

questions.question_text:
The help desk informed a security analyst of a trend that is beginning to develop regarding a suspicious email that has been reported by multiple users. The analyst has determined the email includes an attachment named invoice.zip that contains the following files:

Locky.js -
xerty.ini
xerty.lib
Further analysis indicates that when the .zip file is opened, it is installing a new version of ransomware on the devices. Which of the following should be done
FIRST to prevent data on the company NAS from being encrypted by infected devices?

discussion.content: This question was in the exam :)
B is not even close to logical. D should be the answer. What if the employees open the invoice before the email sent by admins?

D is correct.

This is a staged attack, .js file is a downloader and its pure purpose is to download the ransomware. Blocking this will stop the attack.

The answer is D. - Based on "The first stage of a ransomware attack is to get to your machine and execute its files. Once the executable files are run either by a user or another malicious file, it connects to the criminal's Command and Control (C&C) server and sends information about the host machine. This connection is known as call home or C2 traffic and normally uses the standard port 80 and HTTP or port 443 and HTTPS protocols."

First off, this question is sorta screwed up since another version mentions emailing employees while this one doesn't.

The answer is D. Ransomware works by contacting a C&C server. Blocking that domain will be far more effective than telling your employees not to access that domain. B in this case does not work because it's more of a proactive solution. Setting permissions on file-shares MIGHT work, but I'm still confident in D.
B. should be the answer, the most effective way to safeguard your data from ransom ware is by having a backup copy of your data

comments.content:
quick google: https://security.stackexchange.com/questions/116371/is-denying-write-access-an-effective-way-to-stop-ransomware

suggests that in reality D is correct for use in the real world
do you mean letter C? letter C is the one related to that article you mentioned

discussion.content:
I don't think D is the first step to be done. Multiple users have already received the email, so adding the URL where the JS file is received will not prevent data from being encrypted, it will only prevent future downloads of the malicious zip file.

On a side note, will setting permissions to read-only prevent ransomware?

comments.content: he said "the URL included in .js", which means after the .rar is opened the .js is going to execute therefore the proxy filter comes into play

discussion.content: Well, i see the .js file is included in the .zip file which has already made inside the corporate network. What then can the web proxy filter do to it? help me out here. if the .zip file is not opened the installation will not happen. I think B is valid.
They should email employees because the email already sent and sitting in their inboxes...
I take it back. D makes the most sense based on this article: https://community.sophos.com/kb/en-us/124699

I don’t think it’s D. I think the most a web proxy filter will Do is prevent the randsomware from contacting command and control. But the randsomware could still encrypt the user’s data, even without internet access.
should be D

Answer B - Port Scan. 
Look in the log for the incrementing port number 80, 81, 83, 82.. 
Also look at the static destination IP.

comments.content: It's a port scan. At first it look like ping sweep, but at second thought, I realized that they've separated the port and the IP addresses with a dot, so you've to take the first four octets as the IP and the remaining is the port destination.

discussion.content: This is a ping sweep or is it just me.

questions.question_text: A network technician is concerned that an attacker is attempting to penetrate the network, and wants to set a rule on the firewall to prevent the attacker from learning which IP addresses are valid on the network. Which of the following protocols needs to be denied?

discussion.content: Block icmp block command ping

questions.question_text:
A database administrator contacts a security administrator to request firewall changes for a connection to a new internal application.
The security administrator notices that the new application uses a port typically monopolized by a virus.
The security administrator denies the request and suggests a new port or service be used to complete the application's task.
Which of the following is the security administrator practicing in this example?

discussion.content:
The answer is C - 
Why. As the previous peeps said. This talks about ports on a firewall. He does deny it but is using an ACL on the firewall to do so. 
I think that makes sense :-)
I think this one should be "A. Explicit deny". Unless the question is incomplete.

comments.content: The reason why I'm saying A is because of how the question was formulated. What did the Security Analyst do? He EXPLICITLY denied the request.
In that case, the question is phrased in a way that is confusing, me thinks, because that's not the way I understand it.

No he is NOT practising creating an ACL here, lol
He denied the request. An explicit deny. Thats all

Its an ACL The question specifically calls out a firewall and ports and services. The admin does not use Explicit Deny because the rule is already in place through the use of ACLs, he denied the DBA's request to change the ACL.

Implicit and Explicit Deny in Firewalls is not about allowing or denying a request for a firewall change.
Explicit Allow or Deny Firewall rules are the ones that you create to allow or deny traffic in your firewall rules. 
e.g. ALLOW TCP 192.168.1.6 ANY 100.123.124.125 80
Implicit deny are usually set by the system, 
e.g. DENY ANY ANY
Implicit Deny at the end of the firewall rule lists to deny traffic that does not fall under the explicit allow lists.

In this question, the security administrator denied the database administrators request, (does not mean explicit firewall deny) but essentially, all the rules in the firewall is your "Access Control List"

Hope this helps :)
I chuckled a bit because you're right. The security analyst EXPLICITLY denied the request hahahaha but what he is "practicing" here is creating an ACL.
